document_title: Blocking SARS-CoV-2 Delta Variant (B.1.617.2) Spike Protein Receptor-Binding Domain Binding with the ACE2 Receptor of the Host Cell and Inhibiting Virus Infections Using Human Host Defense Peptide-Conjugated Graphene Quantum Dots
summary_full: This study reports the development of human host defense peptide-conjugated graphene quantum dots (GQDs) as a strategy to inhibit SARS-CoV-2 delta variant (B.1.617.2) infections. The researchers conjugated neutrophil Î±-defensin HNP1 and cathelicidin LL-37 peptides onto GQDs. These peptide-conjugated GQDs were shown to effectively bind to the spike protein receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the delta variant, with a binding affinity comparable to the ACE2-spike protein interaction. The binding of the peptide-GQDs to the spike protein resulted in fluorescence quenching, indicating a strong interaction. Further experiments using HEK293T cells expressing ACE2 demonstrated that the peptide-conjugated GQDs completely inhibited the entry of delta variant SARS-CoV-2 pseudovirions into host cells by blocking the ACE2-spike protein binding. The combination of both HNP1 and LL-37 peptides on GQDs showed higher inhibition efficiency than single-peptide conjugates or peptides alone. Additionally, TEM and SEM imaging revealed that the peptide-conjugated GQDs could damage the virus's lipid membrane, leading to virus collapse and removal of spike proteins, thus preventing infection.
key_findings: Human host defense peptides (HNP1 and LL-37) conjugated to graphene quantum dots (GQDs) effectively bind to the SARS-CoV-2 delta variant spike protein RBD.
The binding affinity of peptide-conjugated GQDs to the delta variant spike protein RBD is comparable to the ACE2-spike protein binding affinity (approximately 8-9 nM).
The delta variant spike protein exhibits higher binding affinity to the peptide-conjugated GQDs compared to alpha, beta, and gamma variants.
Peptide-conjugated GQDs completely inhibit the entry of delta variant SARS-CoV-2 pseudovirions into host cells by blocking ACE2-spike protein interaction.
Dual peptide (HNP1 and LL-37) conjugated GQDs show significantly higher inhibition efficiency than single-peptide conjugates or peptides alone.
Peptide-conjugated GQDs can disrupt the viral lipid membrane, contributing to virus inactivation.
future_research_fields: In vivo efficacy studies of peptide-conjugated GQDs against SARS-CoV-2 delta variant infections.
Development of therapeutic strategies utilizing peptide-conjugated nanomaterials for broad-spectrum antiviral applications.
Investigation of the long-term effects and potential toxicity of peptide-conjugated GQDs in biological systems.
Exploration of other host defense peptides and nanomaterials for enhanced antiviral activity.
Further characterization of the interaction mechanisms between peptide-conjugated GQDs and viral proteins.
related_papers: Science, 2021, 371, 1103-1104. Immunity to Sars-Cov-2 Variants of Concern.
Nature, 2021, 593, 130-135. Antibody resistance of SARS-CoV-2 variants B.1.351 and B.1.1.7.
ACS Cent. Sci. 2021, 7, 156-163. Novo Discovery of High-Affinity Peptide Binders for the SARS-CoV-2 Spike Protein.
ACS Infect. Dis. 2021, 7, 1545-7,1554. Human Cathelicidin Inhibits SARS-CoV-2 Infection: Killing Two Birds with One Stone.
Gastroenterology 2020, 159, 1145-1147.e4. Human Intestinal Defensin 5 Inhibits SARS-CoV-2 Invasion by Cloaking ACE2.
conclusions: Human host defense peptide-conjugated graphene quantum dots (HNP1 and LL-37) effectively block the binding of the SARS-CoV-2 delta variant spike protein RBD to ACE2, thereby inhibiting viral entry into host cells. The dual-peptide conjugation enhances inhibition efficiency, and the GQDs also contribute to virus inactivation by disrupting the viral membrane. These findings suggest a promising therapeutic approach against SARS-CoV-2 variants.
impact_statement: This research presents a novel nanomaterial-based strategy using peptide-conjugated graphene quantum dots to effectively block SARS-CoV-2 delta variant entry into host cells, offering a potential new avenue for antiviral therapies.
